body.p:
To his Excellency Thomas E Bramlette
Govenor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your petitioner Jno W Harris states that several years ago, he was in the city of Lexington and from some cause, for which he can not now account, got into a condition, as he is told and believes, of intoxication to an extent that rendered him utterly incapable of distinguishing between right and wrong and whilst in this condition he became engaged in a difficulty with one James Harkins, and inflicted upon him wounds with a Knife. For this offence he was indicted in the Fayette Circuit Court, and at the August term thereof 1865. upon trial fined $250.x

He states that he has no doubt he committed the act but he has no recollection of it. That he is not in the habit of intoxication: That he for a support for himself and family depends and is compelled to depend on his daily exertions, and to pay said fine would sorely distress him and his family.
He would therefore ask your excellency to remit the fine so far as you can, and by so doing confer on one of your citizens as a lasting obligation
